t: Numbers 24
Now*p when Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord*s to bless Israel, he did not go as at other times, to seek to use sorcery, but he set his face toward the wilderness.
And Balaam raised his eyes, and saw Israel encamped according to their tribes; and the Spirit of God came upon him.
Then*p he took up his oracle and said: “The*pn utterance of Balaam the son of Beor, The*ld utterance of the man whose eyes are opened,
The*ld utterance of him who hears the words of God, Who*ld sees the vision of the Almighty, Who*ld falls down, with eyes wide open:
“How*ln lovely are your tents, O Jacob! Your*ld dwellings, O Israel!
Like*ld valleys that stretch out, Like*ld gardens by the riverside, Like*ld aloes planted by the Lord,*s Like*ld cedars beside the waters.
He*ld shall pour water from his buckets, And*ld his seed shall*i be*i in many waters. “His*ln king shall be higher than Agag, And*ld his kingdom shall be exalted.
“God*ln brings him out of Egypt; He*ld has strength like a wild ox; He*ld shall consume the nations, his enemies; He*ld shall break their bones And*ld pierce them*i with his arrows.
‘He*ld bows down, he lies down as a lion; And*ld as a lion, who shall rouse him?’ “Blessed*ln is*i he who blesses you, And*ld cursed is*i he who curses you.”

Then*p Balak’s anger was aroused against Balaam, and he struck his hands together; and Balak said to Balaam, “I called you to curse my enemies, and look, you have bountifully blessed them*i these three times!
Now therefore, flee to your place. I said I would greatly honor you, but in fact, the Lord*s has kept you back from honor.”
So*p Balaam said to Balak, “Did I not also speak to your messengers whom you sent to me, saying,
‘If Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond the word of the Lord,*s to do good or bad of my own will. What the Lord*s says, that I must speak’?
And now, indeed, I am going to my people. Come, I will advise you what this people will do to your people in the latter days.”
Balaam’s Fourth Prophecy
So*p he took up his oracle and said: “The*pn utterance of Balaam the son of Beor, And*ld the utterance of the man whose eyes are opened;
The*ld utterance of him who hears the words of God, And*ld has the knowledge of the Most High, Who*ild sees the vision of the Almighty, Who*ild falls down, with eyes wide open:

“I*ln see Him, but not now; I*ld behold Him, but not near; A*ld Star shall come out of Jacob; A*ld Scepter shall rise out of Israel, And*ld batter the brow of Moab, And*ld destroy all the sons of tumult.
“And*ln Edom shall be a possession; Seir*ld also, his enemies, shall be a possession, While*ld Israel does valiantly.
Out*ld of Jacob One shall have dominion, And*ld destroy the remains of the city.”
Then*p he looked on Amalek, and he took up his oracle and said: “Amalek*pn was*i first among the nations, But*ld shall*i be*i last until he perishes.”
Then*p he looked on the Kenites, and he took up his oracle and said: “Firm*pn is your dwelling place, And*ld your nest is set in the rock;
Nevertheless*ld Kain shall be burned. How*ld long until Asshur carries you away captive?”
Then*p he took up his oracle and said: “Alas!*pn Who shall live when God does this?
But*ld ships shall*i come*i from the coasts of Cyprus, And*ld they shall afflict Asshur and afflict Eber, And*ld so shall Amalek,*i until he perishes.”
So*p Balaam rose and departed and returned to his place; Balak also went his way.
